Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(2) Summary

APIs are getting recognized as being strategic in many organizations, and yet there often isn't an explicit API strategy or program in place. As the API sector matures there are emerging patterns how to approach API strategies and programs within organizations. Depending on how far along on their API journey an organization is, there are various patterns and none of those are right or wrong, they just are different stages in the strategic use of APIs. We look at some of these patterns and will look at them in the context of API strategies and their execution.



Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(3) Getting APIs to Work

(5) The Spice Girls Question



Introduction Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(6) The General Driver: Digital Transformation

Digital Transformation means adapting an organization's strategy and structure to capture opportunities enabled by digital technology. (Nathan Furr and Andrew Shipilov, Digital Doesn't Have to Be Disruptive, Harvard Business Review 97(4), July/August 2019, pp. 94-103) [https://hbr.org/2019/07/digital-doesnt-have-to-be-disruptive]



Introduction Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(7) Typical API Drivers

  1. More ways of interfacing with partners and/or public (inside-out)
  2. Faster flow of change and faster feedback cycles (inside-in)
  3. Increased focus on differentiating capabilities (outside-in)


Introduction Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(8) There is no API Strategy

  • There shouldn't be a standalone API strategy
  • Business strategy should be driving the digital strategy
  • Digital strategy should be driving the API strategy
  • API strategy can always be traced back to business strategy


Introduction Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

Programs & Platforms Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(11) Strategy Execution: API Program

  • APIs are popping up like mushrooms
  • API designers and developers should get support
  • API consumers should get coherence
  • API programs often see two development phases
    1. Centralization to achieve economies of scale
    2. Decentralization to remove bottlenecks and increase flow


Programs & Platforms Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(12) Program Foundation: API Platform

  • Often a side-effect of entering the decentralization phase
  • Self-service with the goal of increasing developer autonomy and flow
  • Automating non-differentiating and not-unimportant tasks


Programs & Platforms Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(13) Know Your Platforms: Different Platform Types

  • API Platform: For external users (partners and/or public)
  • Internal Developer Platform (IDP): API platform (private) + DevOps tooling
  • Platform Business: Having a multi-sided business model


Programs & Platforms Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

Team Structure Matters Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(16) Conway's Law

Any organization that designs a system (defined broadly) will produce a design whose structure is a copy of the organization's communication structure. [http://www.melconway.com/Home/Conways_Law.html] (Mel Conway [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melvin_Conway])


Team Structure Matters Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(17) Consequences of Conway's Law

  • Technical leaders must have a say about organization design
  • Not all collaboration/communication is good
  • Four types of teams:
    • Stream-aligned: Deliver value with minimal hands-offs
    • Enabling: Grow capabilities of stream-aligned teams
    • Complicated-subsystem: Reduce cognitive load of stream-aligned teams
    • Platform: Make stream-aligned teams autonomous

API Guidelines Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(19) API Guidelines as Shared Practices

  • More API teams mean more ways to solve the same problem
    • Solving API problems is not what teams should focus on
    • Solving API problems in a consistent way helps the API landscape
  • Communications across teams is a challenge
    • Complement channels with documentation of practices


API Guidelines Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(20) The Anatomy of a Good Guideline

  • Why does the guideline exist?
    • Rationale for creating the guideline
  • What can be done to address the described issue
    • At least one good solution for addressing the issue
  • How to implement the solution
    • At least one way to use the solution in practice
  • Testing that the guideline has been followed
    • Some tests can be automated but many will be by declaration or review


API Guidelines Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(25) The End of Full Lifecycle API Management

Source: Mark O'Neill (Gartner): The End of Full Lifecycle API Management



The Great Unbundling Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(26) Diversity in the API Space

  • More API styles
  • More deployment models
  • Larger set of API users
  • Growing landscape of service providers

Conclusions Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution

(31) Manage Your API Journey

  • Developers: Help your platform (team) to evolve
  • Platforms: Talk to your developers and track the API landscape
  • Business: Become API literate and drive business block discussions


Conclusions Erik Wilde: API Strategy Execution
